intro: Cinchona heterophylla, commonly known as the Andean quinine tree, is a species native to the Andean regions of South America. It is a member of the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and striking, showy flowers. The plant typically grows as a small to medium-sized tree, reaching heights of up to 10 meters. Its leaves are elliptical with a smooth margin, and it produces clusters of small, white to pinkish flowers. The plant is notable for its historical significance in the production of quinine, a compound used in the treatment of malaria.
